Desmond: I think if I'm wearing makeup and I'm presenting masculine and someone feels uncomfortable with that... One, I don't care. And two, part of me is like, "Good. You deserve to sort of have those wires crossed for you a little bit, because those wires aren't as straight in real life as you think they are."

Jen: I don't really identify with any gender... No shade but all of this gender stuff seems like a scam no matter how you do it or don't do it. I think the scam is when you walk into a store and like it says, boy's, girl's, men's, women's... You can literally shop anywhere in the store if you aren't afraid to. And part of the scam is like, selling people gender.

Paulina: When I was younger and people like, told me I was a girl and told me I needed to be certain things, it made me reject femininity. So I didn't like skirts, I didn't like accessories, I didn't like pink. Once I realized that I was nonbinary, I began to be more feminine because to me being feminine wasn't associated with being a girl anymore. So I embraced that.

Desmond: There are some days where I'll like wear makeup in addition to presenting pretty masculine, and my voice is deep, and I look like a dude, or whatever. Even then I am much more comfortable with being read as a man wearing makeup, even though I am nonbinary. If you're visibly gender nonconforming then you're, you know, potentially targeted for violence. And that's not good.

Jen: Like sometimes, if I want to go to the store and I don't want to be harassed, like, I'm able to throw on something more masc or whatever, and not be bothered. Or if I want to go on a date, and I don't want the person know I'm femme, I just have to like, wear a hat and take off my nail polish. It feels nasty to be like, I can just do this.

Paulina: I dress really feminine and I sound really feminine, so I never expect somebody to think I'm nonbinary because there's no indication of that. That's always in the back of my mind when I start talking to somebody like, are they really seeing me how I see myself? Are they really understanding what I'm trying to get across?

Jen: How I have moved in society and like the world, from being told that I had to be masculine, to being told that I was too feminine-- and then once you've been feminine for a while like an assigned male at birth person you're like trans-feminine, trans-masculine... Those are descriptors for experiences, less than who we are.
